questions.text: Which of the following is common soil transmitted helminthic infection in India is Characterized by eggs in stool shown is the figure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trichuris Trichuris trichiura eggs are barrel-shaped, thick-shelled and possess a pair of polar “plugs” at each end. The eggs are unembryonated when passed in stool So according to this information the picture of egg in question showing brown colour, barrel shaped and bipolar mucus plug is indicative of Trichuris trichiura egg.

Table:

#MANTRA Egg. Stained. Shape. Colour Trichuris. Double bile stained. Barrel shaped. Brown Ascaris. Double bile stained. Spherical/Oval. Brown Enterobius Non bile stained Elongate/Oval Non Stain Ancylostoma. Non bile stained Oval / thin-shelled bodies Non Stain

questions.text: The following is not true about JE?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Humans are reservoir Japanese encephalitis (JE)? JE is mosquito borne viral infection Virus - Flavivirus Vector - Culex Host - Pigs and wading birds are the main carriers of the Japanese encephalitis virus Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) cannot transmit from one person to another. JEV is related to the viruses that cause St. Louis encephalitis and Murray Valley encephalitis, West Nile virus, dengue fever, and yellow fever. Encephalitis is an inflammation of the brain that can cause fever, headache, confusion, seizures, and, in some cases, death.

questions.text: A 12 years old boy presents with vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. What is the likely causative organism responsible for the symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Staphylococcus aureus Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus cereus (emetic type) have incubation period of less than 6hrs. rest all food poisoning microorganisms like Salmonella, clostridium have incubation period of more than 6 hrs so in this question boys developed food poisoning due to S. aureus. Salmonella enteritidis - Most persons infected with Salmonella bacteria develop diarrhea, fever, and abdominal cramps 12 to 72 hours after infection Staph aureus - Staph food poisoning is characterized by a sudden start of nausea, vomiting, and stomach cramps. Most people also have diarrhea. Symptoms usually develop within 30 minutes to 8 hours after eating or drinking an item containing Staph toxin, and last no longer than 1 day. Clostridium Botulinum - In food-borne botulism, signs and symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea followed by constipation and abdominal distention. There may be weakness and difficulty breathing. Symptoms normally appear between 18 and 36 hours after consuming the contaminated food, but this can vary between 3 hours and 8 days Clostridium perfringens - Symptoms of perfringens food poisoning include intense abdominal cramps and watery diarrhea. Your symptoms usually appear 6 to 24 hours after eating foods containing large numbers of C. perfringens . The disease usually is over within 24 hours. Less severe symptoms may last for 1 or 2 weeks Right answer in this context would be staphylococcus aureus food poisoning as symptoms develops within 3-4 hrs

questions.text: Super antigen is produced by which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Streptococcus pyogenes Several bacterial species, mostly Staphylococcus aureus ( S. aureus ) and Streptococcus pyogenes ( S. pyogenes ), as well as some viruses, release superantigens.

questions.text: Maternal antibodies do not provide protective immunity to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Polio Maternal antibodies do not provide protective immunity to polio. Therefore, Zero dose is the first dose of oral polio vaccine given institutionally soon after birth. DPT vaccine should be given at 6,10 & 14 weeks

questions.text: A 5 years old boy presents with sore throat for the last two days. On examination he has a greyish white pseudo membrane around his tonsils. Diphtheria is suspected. What prophylactic step should be taken for the 3 years old younger sibling who has received immunization as per the schedule?

options.label: B
options.text: Prophylaxis with erythromycin and diphtheria antitoxin

options.label: D
options.text: Immunize with booster of diphtheria toxoid

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nothing is required As mentioned in the question, his sibling is fully immunized till date so according to the National immunization schedule his siblings have taken all the necessary doses of DPT so right now, nothing is required. After 5-7yr of age his sibling may immunize with booster of diphtheria toxoid

questions.text: Recent influenza a pandemic was due to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

H1N1 In the spring of 2009, a novel influenza A (H1N1) virus emerged. It was detected first in the United States and spread quickly across the United States and the world. This new H1N1 virus contained a unique combination of influenza genes not previously identified in animals or people. This virus was designated as influenza A (H1N1) pdm09 virus. H1N1 flu is also known as swine flu. It's called swine flu because in the past, the people who caught it had direct contact with pigs H- Hemagglutinin N- Neuraminidase

questions.text: Which of the following is a category A bioterrorism agent:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bacillus anthracis All the bioterrorism agents are mentioned in the below table Category Definition of Category Disease Organism(s)/Agent(s) A High- priority agents include organism that pose a risk to national security because they: - Can be easily disseminated or transmitted from person to person - Result in high mortality and have the potential for major public health impact - Might cause public panic and social disruption - Require special action for public health preparedness. Anthrax Botulism Plague Smallpox Tularemia Viral hemorrhagic fevers Bacillus anthracis Clostridium botulinum toxin Yersinia pestis Variola major Francisella tularensis Filoviruses (eg, Ebola, Marburg) Arena viruses (eg, Lassa, Machupo) B Second highest priority agents include those that: - Result in moderate easy to disseminate - Result in moderate morbidity rates and low mortality - Require specific enhancements of laboratory diagnostic capacity and enhanced disease surveillance Brucellosis Epsilon toxin Food safely threats Glanders melioidosis Psittacosis Q fever Ricin toxin Typhus fever Viral encephalitis Staphylococcal enterotoxin B Water safety threats Brucella species Clostridium perfringens Salmonella species, Escherichia coli O157:H7, Shigella, and so forth Burkholderia mallei Burkholderia pseudomallei Chlamydia psittaci Coxiella burnetii Ricinus communis (castor beans) Staphylococcus aureus Rickettsia prowazekii Alphaviruses (e.g. Venezuelan equine encephalitis, eastern equine encephalitis Vibrio cholerae, Cryptosporidium parvum and so forth C Third highest priority agents include emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future because of: - Availability - Ease of production and dissemination - Potential for high morbidity and mortality and major health impact Emerging infectious diseases Nipah virus Hantavirus - Tick-borne hemorrhagic fever viruses - Tick-borne encephalitis viruses - Yellow fever - Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be acquired by traumatic inoculation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sporothrix Schenckii Sporotrichosis, caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii, is currently distributed throughout the world, especially in tropical and subtropical zones. Infection generally occurs by traumatic inoculation of soil, plants, and organic matter contaminated with the fungus. As all the mentioned organisms in the question are Dimorphic fungi Except Sporothrix schenckii all three fungi acquired in body through inhalation

questions.text: Shown in the figure is the HBV test. Which of the following is the principle of this test?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immunochromatography HBsAg card test based on the principle of immunochromatography, a unique assay based on antigen capture or sandwich principle The method uses monoclonal antibodies conjugated to colloidal gold and polyclonal antibodies immobilized on nitrocellulose strips in a thin line. pribiciple of ict: T he immunochromatographic test principle is based on immunoaffinity partition of the analyte between sample migrating laterally through a porous membrane and a finite “affinity zone” prepared by immobilizing an antibody on the membrane.

questions.text: Which is the following is the vector for Zika virus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aedes aegypti Zika virus causes Zika disease in Human beings Symptoms of Zika infection- Fever. Rash. Headache. Joint pain. Conjunctivitis (red eyes) Muscle pain. Vector for Zika virus- Aedes aegypti

questions.text: Antiseptic property of bleaching powder is due to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypochlorous acid What is Bleaching Powder? Calcium oxychloride (CaOCl2) is known as bleaching powder Action Bleaching powder or Calcium hypochlorite (CaOCl2) is mixed salt have two type of anion Cl-(chloride ion ) and OCl-(hypochlorite ion) .it act as oxidizing agent and bleaching agent Bleaching powder has a lot of uses. It is used for bleaching silk and wool. It is mainly used as a bleaching agent for cotton, linen and wood pulp. Bleaching action of bleaching powder is due to oxidation and it is permanent CaOCl2 + H2O——-Ca(OH)2 + Cl2 Cl2 + H2O——- O +2HCl COLOR+O—-> COLORLESS Bleaching powder is used as disinfectant and germicide especially in the sterilization of drinking water. It is used as an oxidizing agent in many chemical industries to obtain various chemical products. C2H5OH+Cl2—->CH3CHO + 2HC Antiseptic property of breaching powder Bleaching powder releases Hypochlorous acid that causes oxidative damage to the cells

questions.text: A female from a tribal area of Jharkhand reports with fever for the last 3 days. Peripheral blood is collected and stained with Giemsa. A diagnosis of malaria is made. The smear is shown in the figure what is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

P. falciparum P falciparum and P vivax are the most common causes OF malaria Distinguishing features of P. Falciparum & P. Vivax are mentioned below Agent No. of rings/cell No. of nucleus/ring Form P. Falciparum >1 >1 Accolé form P. Vivax 1 1 No accolé form

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12 year-old close friend is in fear of contracting disease. What advice should be given to her:

options.label: D
options.text: No vaccine needed as exposure has already occurred

questions.correct_answer: B. Two doses of Conjugate vaccine
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Two doses of Conjugate vaccine To prevent the occurrence meningococcal meningitis or their serious strain her 12-year-old friend must take two doses of conjugate vaccine as the prophylaxis

Extraedge:

The current available meningococcal vaccines are: Conjugate meningococcal vaccine Monovalent (A or C) meningococcal vaccine, which protects against meningococcal group A and C disease. Monovalent C meningococcal vaccine is recommended for all children at one year of age as part of routine immunization and for people who have had meningococcal disease. Infants aged 2–11 months are given 2 doses with at least 2 months between the doses, followed by a booster dose about one year later. A single dose of monovalent A meningococcal vaccine is licensed for individuals 1–29 years of age. Combined haemophilus influenzae type B (HIB) plus monovalent C meningococcal vaccine. It is recommended that 3 doses administered at 2, 4 and 6 months of age should be followed by a booster at 12–15 months of age. Quadrivalent (A, C, Y and W135), which has been licensed since 2005 for use in children and adults in some countries in the world. This vaccine is initially administered as one dose only and is licensed for individuals 2–55 years of age. A two-dose series of this vaccine is licensed for use in children aged 9–23 months. Polysaccharide meningococcal vaccine This is recommended for some specific risk groups and for the control of meningococcal outbreaks, and is available in different forms. Bivalent: protects against groups A and C. This form is administered as a single dose to persons ≥ 2 years old, which provides protection for 2–3 years. A second single dose is administered for school children and adults, which provides protection for at least 3 years. After 3–5 years, one booster dose may be given to persons considered to be at continued risk of exposure including health workers. Trivalent: protects against groups A, C and W-135 Tetravalent: protects against groups A, C, Y and W-135. This form is recommended for travelers to countries where there are epidemics of meningococcal disease (eg. sub-Saharan Africa and people travelling to perform Hajj in Saudi Arabia). These vaccines do not protect against meningococcal groups B and X. Serogroup B vaccines have been extracted from selected outbreak strains and are currently used in some countries to limit outbreaks.

questions.text: An HIV positive patient with a CD4 count of 300/mm3 presents with mucosal lesion in the mouth. On microscopy budding yeasts and pseudo hyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Candidiasis Candidiasis is a fungal infection due to any type of Candida . When it affects the mouth, it is commonly called thrush. Signs and symptoms include white patches on the tongue or other areas of the mouth and throat Risk factors Immunosuppression (HIV/AIDS), diabetes, corticosteroids

Highyeild:

questions.explanation:

Fimbriae Cytoplasmic membrane helps in performing vital functions Mesosomes helps in Respiration Fimbriae and Pili helps in bacterial adhesion Lipopolysaccharide is the outer layer in gram negative bacteria

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of donovanosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Klebsiella granulomatis Donovanosis is a sexually transmissible genital ulcer disease. The bacterium that causes donovanosis (Klebsiella granulomatis) infects the skin around the genitals, groin or anal area and causes ulcers and destruction of the skin. Haemophilus ducreyi - It causes the sexually transmitted disease chancroid Leishmania donovani- It causes leishmaniasis or kala azar Treponema Pallidum- It causes syphilis, causing primary indurated painless genital ulcer.

Highyeild:

Causes of Genital Ulcerations DISEASE TYPE OF LESION TYPE OF INGUINAL ADENOPATHY DIAGNOSIS Genital herpes Multiple grouped vesicles to coalesced ulcers, painful Tender, discrete, nonsuppurative Culture, enzyme immunoassay Chancroid Tender, shallow, painful ulcer, not indurated ulcer Suppurative Culture Syphilis Nontender, indurated ulcer Rubbery consistency Darkfield exam, serology Lymphogranuloma venereum Painless, small ulcer or papule, usually healed at time of presentation Discrete progressing to suppurative, draining fistulas Culture, serology Granuloma inguinale Papular to nodular to ulcerative lesion(s), painless "Pseudobubo" caused by induration of subcutaneous tissue in inguinal area Giemsa stain of biopsy

questions.text: Urethritis in male is not caused by-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

H. ducreyi Urethritis in male is caused by Gonococcal which includes Gonococcal and Nongonococcal includes Mycoplasma, Ureaplasma, Chlamydia And parasitic and fungal causes includes Trichomonas, candida So H. ducreyi doesn’t cause urethritis in male, it causes genital ulcers. (1- 70%) - Yeast. - HSV -Trauma -Urethral stricture. -Catheterization. -Chemical irritants. -Dehydration.

questions.text: The immunoglobulin structure shown in the figure belongs to which class of antibody:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

lgA Ig A antibody occurs in dimeric form as shown in the image with J-chain also. IgM occurs in pentavalent forms so the right answer to this question is IgA.
